Award.AwardTitle: Translational Patterns During Spermiogenesis in Marsilea

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to elucidate the mechanisms that control cell fate determination in the male gametophyte of the fern Marsilea vestita. Specifically, studies will focus on the spatial and temporal regulation of translation that underlies basal body formation and nuclear remodeling in the spermatids. Spermatogenesis in this fern is a process that is activated by placing dry spores into water and involves a series of nine rapid cell division cycles in precise planes within the spore wall to produce 32 spermatids and 7 sterile cells. There is no movement of cells, so size and position within the spore wall defines cell fate. Gametophyte development takes place in the absence of new transcription; instead, the gametes are formed with proteins that were already present in the spore, or translated from mRNAs that had been transcribed and stored prior to spore desiccation. Within the spermatids, differentiation involves the formation of basal bodies in the absence of preexisting centrioles in a unique particle known as a blepharoplast. The spermatids then form an elaborate signature microtubule cytoskeleton known as the multilayered structure (MLS). The later phases of spermatid maturation involve nuclear remodeling, cell reshaping, and finally ciliogenesis, to produce a multiciliated, spirally-shaped motile gamete that looks nothing like the cell that gave rise to it. None of these events occurs in the sterile cells, though all of the cells present within the spore wall arose from the same progenitor. Thus, the male gametophyte of Marsilea provides a unique opportunity to study multiple aspects of cellular differentiation in populations of synchronously developing cells, where the cells are permeable to the entry of macromolecules at the time the spores are placed into water. The specific objectives of this project are to (1) determine how the core components of the exon junction complex affect patterns of centrin translation essential for the process of de novo basal body formation; (2) characterize the RNA-binding proteins that regulate the abundance of alpha-tubulin, which, together with centrin, affects basal body production and formation of the MLS; and (3) determine how spermidine affects temporal and spatial patterns of translation, thereby influencing cell fate specification within the gametophyte.

This project will provide research training and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral associates and visiting scholars. In addition, laboratory courses have been developed that provide training in cell biology and microscopy for undergraduate and graduate students and a website focused on an "Introduction to Mitosis" has been developed and is accessible by the public at http://www.life.umd.edu/CBMG/faculty/wolniak/wolniakmitosis.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A variety of cells from widely diverse organisms undergo periods of extended quiescence (e.g., desiccating organisms, hibernating organisms, some plants, and metazoan oocytes) and then, in response to a stimulus, exhibit a burst of protein synthesis, using stored mRNAs to drive rapid development. Prior to quiescence, the cells engage in the synthesis of large quantities of RNAs, which are stored during quiescence and used during the rapid developmental burst. We are studying the mechanisms that control this rapid process in male gametophytes of the semi-aquatic fern, Marsilea vestita. When naturally desiccated microspores of M. vestita are immersed in water, the single progenitor cell undergoes 9 rapid successive division cycles to produce 32 spermatids and 7 sterile cells. The spermatids undergo profound compositional and organizational changes to become multiciliated gametes that resemble no other cells in the entire organism. The gametophyte provides ready (arguably unparalleled) access for the study of regulatory mechanisms controlling morphogenesis in cells predisposed for rapid development upon exiting an extended period of quiescence. Our work has shown that gametophyte development is controlled by multiple post- transcriptional regulatory processes. Stored pre-mRNAs essential for gamete formation are unmasked, processed and translated into proteins at particular times and in specific cells during development. In the desiccated spore, these essential RNA molecules are stored in RNA-aggregate particles we identified as nuclear speckles. The speckles form as the spore undergoes its natural drying process, and they are disassembled when the spore is rehydrated. Our RNA analyses have been greatly aided by the adaptation of next-generation sequencing (RNA-seq) for the generation of a transcriptome from the developing gametophyte. Our sequencing efforts allowed us to identify thousands of types of mRNAs present in the gametophyte, and our isolation strategy has enabled us to discern the abundance of different RNAs during different stages of development. A most surprising finding was that many of the RNAs present in the gametophyte are stored as partially processed pre-transcripts; >9000 different kinds of pre-mRNAs exist as intron retaining transcripts (IRTs), which must be spliced in order to be translated into proteins. Further analysis of the IRTs shows that different RNAs are spliced at different times during gametophyte development, leading us to suspect that the regulation of splicing involves the coordinated association of spliceosome components with particular IRTs at specific times during rapid development. We are now extending these studies, by characterizing families of RNAs that change in abundance at different times during development. Functional silencing assays have shown that transcripts that become abundant late in development play essential roles in cytoskeletal formation and in the assembly of the ciliary axonemes, which are dominant features of this ciliated spermatozoid.
